foreign.shortdesc: Glossary terms for Extreme Event Solutions (EES).

glossentry.glossdef: An active layer is the layer currently visible and enabled in the pane.This can be a map, program, or portfolio layer.
A feature that allows you to view and manage activities such as import, export, and loss analysis.
The state of any activity in the .
Loss of use, or time element for residential properties that are not inhabitable. Relocation and temporary lodging costs are considered. Coverage D.

A numerical value or percentage applied to a base analysis to refine the predicted outcomes. Adjustment factors can be cumulative. You can customize them in your analysis by compensating for variations in company, program, and exposure data.
A function that applies customizations to a loss analysis.
An analysis of evaluating the total risk across a portfolio, region, or group of aggregate exposures such as market shares or sums insured by subarea and line of business.

glossdef.p: A reinsurance program in which a reinsurer indemnifies the ceding company for that portion of the loss that exceeds the limit of its own retention for a given year.

glossentry.glossdef: An exposure expressed as some sort of aggregate value, as in sums insured, premiums, number of risks, rates, payroll, market shares, loss market shares, and custom LOB, rather than by individual contract terms or replacement values.
The maximum loss that can be incurred by a layer across all occurrences within each year.
The loss resulting from all events that occurred during a specified period.
Aggregate loss distributed over a 12-month period.
A binary file that contains event-level loss data consolidated by country. It is a vehicle for sending loss data on your book or portions of your book to retrocessionaires for pricing.

The value below which the year's total occurrence losses (otherwise recoverable) are not assumed by the layer. Applicable only to ground-up, quota share, aggregate excess of loss, and catastrophe bond programs.
An online service providing up-to-date information and loss estimates for natural catastrophes worldwide.
Data that is supplied by 's ALERT™ ( Loss Estimates in Real Time) online service which provides up-to-date information and loss estimates for major natural catastrophes worldwide.
An object storage service in which customers can store data and pay for the service based on usage.
The world’s most comprehensive and broadly adopted cloud platform.

A database that contains reinsurance information you can use to derive and calculate market shares. To produce the database, A.M. Best compiles data from the year-end annual reports of more than 2,000 companies.

Verisk's software analytics suite designed for the reinsurance and insurance industries. The suite takes loss data in a variety of forms and allows for visual mapping of that loss and its analysis through tables, charts and similar analysis tools.
The maximum loss that a layer can incur for all occurrences within a 12-month period.

glossdef.p: The loss resulting from all events that occurred during a contract period (12 months is most common). It is calculated by dividing the sum of all losses in a simulation by the total simulation years.

glossentry.glossdef: 's cloud branded product used by clients to host application environments on the instance on the AWS.

​​'s software analytics suite designed for the reinsurance and insurance industries. The ​Analyze Re​​ suite takes loss data in a variety of forms and allows for visual mapping of that loss and its analysis through tables, charts, and similar analysis tools.
An aggregate loss distributed over the 12 month period. The annual aggregate loss distribution shows the probability distribution of annual aggregate losses.
The annual aggregate retention is a value below which the total losses for a 12-month period are not assumed by the layer.
The largest loss resulting from all events that occurred during a 12-month period. Used in reinsurance and can apply to a risk, policy, company, or contract.
The occurrence loss distributed over a 12-month period. The annual aggregate occurrence distribution shows the probability distribution of annual occurrence losses.
A server that hosts applications or software that delivers a business application through a communication protocol.

A parameter used by the application to filter by geographic area(s) and define where layer terms are applied. In the case of pro rata treaties; this also defines the percent ceded in each geographic area covered by the treaty.

A parameter used by the application to filter events. The feature allows you to manage which events should be considered in a contract analysis based on an event parameter, peril, location, and/or condition. Event filtering includes specifying rules and locations.
A geographic location that is at a higher geographic resolution than a subarea. Areas are defined using the or standards.
Indicates the level of geographic resolution to be used when analyzing this program. Can be either high (subarea) or low (area).
A fee imposed on members of an insurance association for certain qualifying events.
The average loss across all simulated years in a loss analysis.
Maps used in the application to provide a geographic setting for your exposure data.
BINS are IDs which insurers and reinsurers use to identify whether an address represents a building, a unit in a building, a site, or a campus.
A single limit that applies to multiple locations in a contract.
Loss of use or time element for non-residential structures. Business interruption losses are based on the expected number of days that a building is unusable.
Catalogs are lists of events used to calculate potential loss. Common catalog types include , , and .
Risk-linked securities which transfer a specific set of risks from a ceding company to capital market investors for a specific rate of return.
A reinsurance program in which the ceding company is indemnified for the portion of the loss that exceeds the limit of its own retention per event.
An open data format to facilitate accurate and transparent data exchange throughout the insurance industry.
The portions of the obligations in an insurance company’s policy portfolio transferred to a reinsurer.
A device that communicates with a server, such as a desktop computer, laptop, smart phone, or network-compatible device.
A network of remote servers that operate as a single ecosystem.
Describes applications designed to run on the cloud, rather than on-premises networks.
A group of districts within a state in India, used by the Indian crop insurance market.
The portion of the losses to a layer covered by a reinsurer. Where coinsurance and gross/net participation are all specified, the participation % is applied to the treaty’s share of coinsured losses.
A simple text file that stores data in columns separated by commas.
The loss a company is estimated to have from an event, excluding any program/treaty terms.
The result of a detailed loss analysis associated with a cedant company. The results are saved at (sub)area and LOB resolution and may contain one or more perspectives.

glossdef.ph: Files that contain losses by line of business, area, and subarea for each event. They are used in aggregate analyses.

glossentry.glossdef: A trigger that excludes occurrences from consideration in a loss calculation. If the company loss is above the company loss maximum value, then the loss value of the occurrence is set to zero.
A trigger which excludes occurrences from consideration in a loss calculation. If the company loss is below the company loss minimum value, then the loss value of the occurrence is set to zero.
A percentage indicating the amount of the total insured property covered by a specified company in a certain geographic area/subarea and line of business.
Measures the extent to which the losses for the coverages associated with a single location are dependent on each other.

A computing model in which one or more client computers are connected to a central server over a network or internet connection. The server hosts, delivers, and manages most of the client’s resources and services.
Comonotonic distribution methodology where loss distributions are aggregated assuming that losses are maximally correlated.
A class of code that identifies the primary type of construction for a location, such as wood frame or reinforced concrete.
A contract gain is an adjustment associated with portfolio analyses.
An insurance policy.
Loss attributed to individual reinsurance contracts.
Convolution is a methodology where loss distributions are aggregated assuming that losses are completely independent from each other.
A processor in a computer that executes programs.
A component of insurable property that describes what the insurance policy covers.
A value that denotes coverage-specific deductibles and limits. It can be specified as whole numbers or as a percentage of insured/replacement value.
See .
The percentage of company loss of a particular LOB to consider when applying financial terms.
A retired feature.
A geographical data aggregation system that defines country-specific zones. It is used to manage and report on exposure data.

glossBody.glossSurfaceForm: Catastrophe Risk Evaluation and Standardizing Target Accumulations (CRESTA)

glossentry.glossdef: The period in which a specific crop or group of crops are planted and harvested.
Damage factors applied to catastrophe models customize losses based on the experiences of a company.
A third-party database tool application.
The amount of loss retained by the insured; also called .
A multiplicative factor used to account for the effects of short-term inflation in the prices of labor and materials following a catastrophe.
A list of specific policies and locations, with location attributes such as construction/occupancy, year built, and replacement cost by coverage. Contrasts with .
An encrypted file that contains company losses by geographic area and line of business for each simulated event.
A catastrophic event with predefined characteristics, typically used to assess potential losses. There is no probability distribution for deterministic events.
The process of distributing aggregate exposure data from a coarse resolution to a finer resolution; more suitable for detailed catastrophe modeling.
The format used to transfer loss files from to
Files used to map events between versions of select U.S. models.
The location on the earth’s surface directly above the point of an earthquake's initial rupture.
The set of loss files used in a detailed or aggregate loss analysis.
A variable that describes an aspect of an event.
A set of probabilities and return periods that appear in loss analysis results. Also see .
The probability that various levels of loss will be exceeded in a given year. An EP curve is the foundation upon which insurers estimate their likelihood of experiencing various levels of loss.

glossentry.glossterm: exceedance probability with secondary uncertainty curve
glossentry.glossdef: An (EP curve) that samples from other points along an event’s probability distribution to derive a secondary view of risk.

glossBody.glossSurfaceForm: exceedance probability with secondary uncertainty (EPSU) curve

glossentry.glossdef: See
An application-generated text file that includes information to communicate loss information between the application and the associated company loss file.
An index of the events in a single or . This index allows the application to quickly locate data records for a particular event.
A set of probabilities and return periods that appear in loss analysis results.
An adjustment made to an EP curve at the program level based on user knowledge of loss experience for a particular model.
Values assigned to a distribution of points (e.g., year, return period, event ID).
Layers of coverage written above the primary coverage because more capacity is required.
The percentage of loss each bond/layer is expected to incur in any given year.
Expiration date is the last day on which coverage for a treaty is effective.
The adjustment factor used to modify company exposures by .
A generic term that refers to any exposed risk (buildings, cars, offshore rigs, employees) and its associated characteristics, such as address, construction/occupancy, and the values.
A feature that was later renamed as Advanced Loss Modification.
Losses paid that exceed a specific amount up to a specified limit. Types of excess of loss reinsurance include per risk, catastrophe, per policy, per occurrence, and aggregate.
A curve that shows the probability of experiencing different levels of financial loss. The curve can help you determine the amount of risk to retain or cede.
Item of value at risk (e.g., a house); unit of measurement for risk
A discrete set of related exposure entities, such as locations and contracts, and their related financial terms.
A compiled set of summary information about a group of exposures, either an exposure set or an exposure view.
A user-defined logical view of one or more exposure sets, with optional filters.
Unlikely but scientifically plausible scenarios that cannot be captured by standard stochastic modeling techniques.
Coverage purchased by a primary insurer in which both the primary insurer and the reinsurer usually have the option to accept or reject an individual submission. See also .
Used to name states and counties in numerical format.
Total event losses net of reinstatement premiums but not net of the initial program premium.
The view of loss from an event, depending on whether losses are measured from the ground up or after the application of different insurance or reinsurance terms.

The parameters, such as limits and deductibles, specified in an insurance policy that define the conditions under which the insurer will pay some or all the loss. These may be defined at various levels such as contract, layer, and location, and may apply to its entirety or to specific perils and/or coverages.
The side of a volcano.
The vertical distance between where a fault rupture originates and the earth's surface.
The pre-occurrence loss threshold that must be reached before the contract loss will be paid. Also called disappearing deductible.
A security update for the Microsoft SQL server.
The latitude and longitude values and the resolution associated with an individual risk used for modeling in catastrophe modeling.
A vector file format for encoding a variety of geographic data structures.
A vector file format for encoding geometries or geometric characteristics of geographic objects.
The total loss due to an event after applying limits, s, and and before any excess reinsurance terms.
Specifies the percentage of the losses that the reinsurer will assume.
The total loss due to an event before applying financial terms such as limits and s.
A factor or condition that can increase or decrease the probability or severity of a loss from an insured peril (for example, proximity to the coast).
Pertains to the use of the Microsoft© High Performance Computing server, which leverages a distributed computing environment that dramatically reduces run times.
A collection of historical events for a broad area.
A past occurrence of a natural or man-made disaster used as a reference point for modeling and predicting future events.
A collection of historical events for one or more models.
A peril.
Identifies occupancy class codes used to define industrial facilities. Also called the large industrial facility module.
A database of all insurable properties used for estimating potential industry insurance losses for specific geographical regions.
A realistic loss estimate of all insurable properties. It can be calculated by running a detailed loss analysis against the industry exposure database.
The portion of the that is, or is assumed to be, insured. Insured losses include an estimate of the insurance take-up by area, subarea, and line of business.
A file that contains net industry insurable losses after application of primary policies condition assumptions. These losses are grouped by event, geographic area, and .

The value above which occurrences are excluded from consideration. If the industry loss for a given occurrence is above the industry loss maximum value, then the loss value of the occurrence is set to zero.

The value below which occurrences are excluded from consideration. If the industry loss for a given occurrence is below the industry loss minimum value, then the loss value of the occurrence is set to zero.
Specifies the value above or below which occurrences are excluded from consideration based on the industry loss threshold for a given event.
A type of reinsurance contract where one party will purchase protection based on total loss to the insurance industry arising from an event, rather than from their own losses.
Coverage by contract whereby one party undertakes to indemnify or guarantee another against loss by a specified contingency or peril.
The portion of the losses to the layer retained by the cedant.

To take effect for the benefit of either the reinsurer or the reinsured. For example, when layers are applied to reduce the loss to a given layer, those layers are said to inure to the benefit of the reinsurer of that layer.
Inuring loss is the loss reduction applied to company loss after inuring programs and terms are invoked.
Contracts inure in series or in parallel (not both).
Inuring reinsurance programs affect the amount of risk being transferred to or from the reinsured and which contract is affected.
The monetary commitment associated with the bond/layer. For programs only.
An insurance or reinsurance contract with a limit and retention of cover.

The amount of loss ceded to the insurer. This will usually be specified as an amount less than or equal to the replacement value. You can set the limit for individual locations or for an entire policy that covers multiple locations.
See
Terms that apply to a , such as the limit, retention, participation, percent placed, and application of LOBs and geographies.
The limits and deductibles that apply to individual locations and risks.
An attribute of a contract that describes the class of business. These can be user-defined or based on industry definitions such as residential, commercial, auto, etc.
A benchmark rate that some of the world's leading banks charge each other for short-term loans.
Loss files contain data generated to predict losses due to a particular catastrophe.
Company losses generated from a market share analysis on ALERT™ event sets by comparing company loss file losses with the ILF to estimate company market share.
A user-specified adjustment factor that applies to the ground-up losses for a single program.
Time element related to the loss of a structure's functionality due to damage, lack of safety, or lack of access.
A measure of the energy released during an earthquake.
A file that defines data mappings for policy, location, reinsurance, and step function import .csv files.
See
The proportion of the industry written by a company, often expressed as percentages by line of business and area/subarea.
A market trend factor is a user-specified adjustment factor that applies to the losses for a single program.
A program term associated with occurrence limit.
A software development approach in which single-function modules form the basis of the application or deliverable.
The deductible that is applied if the coverage or site deductible is less than the specified minimum level.
A software application that lets users create their own custom models and integrate non- models into applications.
Methodology which combines losses using convolution and comonotonic distributions.
Insurance focussed primarily on crop-related perils and losses.
A cloud computing architecture that enables clients to share computing resources in a public or private cloud. .
Parameter to override program inception date.
The loss after reinsurance treaties have been applied. See and .
The amount that the original reinsurer is responsible for in a .
The total loss generated after the application of all reinsurance treaties, except for treaties.
Losses retained by a ceding company (primary insurer) after netting out reinsurance contract losses and any associated inuring contract losses.
A suite of Microsoft security protocols intended to provide authentication, integrity, and confidentiality to users.
Refers to cases where an insurance company is willing to absorb losses above the retention for the first n-1 occurrences.
The number of property exposures at risk. For workers' compensation exposures, this is the employee count.
An attribute that indicates how a property is used, such as single-family residence or for retail trade.
The maximum loss that can be incurred by a from a single occurrence.
The highest possible loss for the specified period from a single event.
The value below which the does not assume occurrence losses.
A server that is reserved for use by a single entity, such as a business, and that resides in a location managed by that entity.
Information and instructions available with a software application.
A standard that provides the industry with a robust, open, and transparent data format with the aim of delivering a common framework for encoding, transmitting, and interpreting data.
An epidemic of infectious disease that has spread across a large region, multiple countries, continents, or worldwide.
The reinsurers' share of the portfolio.
The ceded amount as a percentage.
A deductible calculated as the percentage of insured loss for the occurrence.
The percentage of the treaty placed with reinsurers.
A category of a catastrophic event that may cause loss and which an insurance policy might cover, such as earthquake shake, hurricane wind, hurricane storm surge, or terrorism. See .
A combination of one or more perils.
In the catastrophe modeling world, a perspective specifies the terms that should apply to the loss results.
A reinsurance program that applies retention and amount of reinsurance for each risk rather than on an aggregate or per-event basis.
A government-sponsored crop insurance scheme for India that integrates multiple stakeholders on a single platform.
The after application of all reinsurance treaties, including XOL treaties. See also .
The after application of all reinsurance treaties except for CatXOL treaties. See also .
A premium type is used to view the loss results net of the reinsurance premium received for the contract. Reinsurance premiums apply to all program types except catastrophe bonds.

The characteristics of a location that determine its risk of damage as a result of a specific peril. For example, occupancy type, construction type, year built, number of stories, replacement value, or latitude and longitude.
Uncertainty in the event generation component of the model (the event catalog). Primary uncertainty has elements of epistemic/aleatory as well as model/parametric uncertainty.
The principal amount associated with the bond/layer.
An event described by probable values for event characteristics.
The probability (%) of a program/layer experiencing some loss.
The probability (%) of a program/layer experiencing a complete loss.
In , a project is a folder where you can assemble navigational shortcuts to related exposure views and analyses.
Refers to map projections that are certified for use in applications.
See and .
A computer programming language that uses queries to request and retrieve data from databases and information systems.
A reinsurance program where the reinsurer is responsible for the same percentage of loss on each risk, regardless of the event or year. Also called proportional reinsurance.
Among other things, the company that maintains realistic disaster scenarios.
Stress test scenarios defined by Lloyd’s of London. They are used to ensure that syndicates meet capacity requirements should an RDS occur.
Specifies the number of times the for the layer can be reinstated during the contract period.

The cost to restore the insurance or reinsurance limit of a contract to its full amount after the insured or reinsured incurs a loss. The term principally relates to property catastrophe reinsurance contracts.

A contract made between an insurance company and a reinsurer to protect the insurance company from losses. The contract provides for the reinsurer to pay for the loss sustained by the insurance company when it makes a payment on the original contract.
A group of related s and layers.
An update for the Microsoft SQL server distributed to manufacturers before being distributed to the general public.
The amount that the insured party would have to pay to replace the insured asset at the present time. Policy terms specify replacement value by location and by coverage.
Losses retained by the insurer.
In terms of , return period is the estimated likelihood of a loss of a given size occurring within a given time frame.
See
An area where a volcano is rifting or splitting apart. Rock in a rift zone has many cracks and is relatively weak.
The treaty limit for a single risk or layer. The risk limit value applies only to treaties of the per-risk treaty type.
The value below which the total losses are not assumed by the layer. Risk retention applies only to treaties of the per-risk treaty type.
The span of the fault that slips during an earthquake.
A secondary effect of a primary peril, such as earthquake sprinkler linkage.
Features of a structure or its environment that affect resistance to damage and modify the base vulnerability functions for a specific peril (also known as ).
Uncertainty associated with the damage and loss estimation should a given event occur.
Identifier used in database implementation for unique identification of a record.
A component-based, modular, and extensible platform for building applications.
A simple, non-topological vector format for storing the geometric location and attribute information of geographic features.
A cloud application and infrastructure environment that serves a single client.
A software licensing model in which access to the software is provided on a subscription basis, with the software being located on external servers rather than on servers located in-house.
A source program (parent) associated with a subject program (child).
The extent to which the losses at two locations behave similarly due to their spatial proximity.
An insurance industry term short for individual location-level (spot) facultative (fac) reinsurance. See .
A database that stores vector files, which are numerical representations of data that capture the semantic meaning of text, images, and other data types.
A catalog of events that reflects hurricane risk under average climate conditions.

An agreement for federal crop insurance that consists of a set of contracts between the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) and private companies. The contracts identify expense reimbursements and risk-sharing by the government on eligible crops.
An integer value that indicates at which event during the year the are to become effective.
Refers to the status of the program or layer. Common status types include: Submitted (default), Authorized, Bound, Cancelled, Quoted, Rejected, and for cat bonds, Investment Status.
Series of simulated events based on one or more stochastic models over a period of time. Stochastic catalogs can be used when running a loss analysis.
An event whose characteristics are obtained from probability distributions in the historical catalog.
A tool for estimating probability distributions of potential outcomes by allowing for random variation in one or more inputs over time.
A programming language for storing and processing information in a relational database. https://aws.amazon.com/what-is/sql/
A type of layer condition that applies to a subset of locations within a policy. Sublimits are often used in high-hazard areas to limit losses for locations that fall within them.
The maximum amount that an insurance company insurance company is obligated to cover in the event of a covered loss.
A reinsurance program where the reinsurer is responsible for the same size of loss on each risk, regardless of the event or year.
Measures the average of all simulated losses from a percentile or return period on the loss distribution through the full "tail" of the loss distribution.

glossdef.p: The percentage of insurable properties actually insured.

glossentry.glossdef: A company loss set or an exposure set.
A catalog of probabilistic events that assumes that the annual probability of a characteristic earthquake occurring on a fault increases with the time elapsed since the previous such earthquake.

Loss of use of a structure over time because due to damage, lack of safety, or lack of access. Loss of use is referred to as additional living expenses for residential properties, and business interruption for other properties (including commercial, industrial, and others).

A catalog of probabilistic events that assumes that the annual probability of a characteristic earthquake occurring on a fault within a given time period is independent of when the last such earthquake occurred and, therefore, requires only knowledge of the mean recurrence time. Compare with .
The minimum of the or the limit minus the deductible. If no layer or policy terms are defined, location values, limits, and deductibles are used.
The sum of the replacement values for all coverages.
A unique identifier provided by the user when creating a program.
Program details.
Coverage purchased by a primary insurer in which the reinsurer must cover any risk that falls within a specified line, class, or book of business. See also .
Characteristics used to define a reinsurance program.

glossdef.p: The mechanism used to determine when payouts must be made. Triggers define company and industry loss parameters and take into consideration the defined geographic region.

glossentry.glossdef: A UJF is a user-defined adjustment factor that applies to ceding company program losses.
Universal Cession Electronic Data Exchange (UNICEDE) is a globally accepted open data format developed by to standardize insurance data exchange.
A loss file whose content must adhere to 's loss file format guidelines.
A control that enables you to specify the order of magnitude at which you want to view monetary figures.
A standard for identifying servers, printers, and other resources on a network, allowing a consistent access to these resources across different systems.
A category which allow you to classify companies and programs using criteria that are meaningful and useful to your specific needs.
Files that contain numerical representations of data that capture the semantic meaning of text, images, and other data types. See .

glossdef.p: The elevated temperature of the ocean's surface, typically measured in the upper few meters. Warm SSTs are crucial in influencing weather patterns, particularly in the formation and intensification of tropical cyclones, hurricanes, and typhoons.

glossentry.glossdef: A catalog of events based on elevated sea surface temperatures.

glossdef.p: Event sets that represent low or very low probability disaster scenarios. See Realistic Disaster Scenarios (RDS), Extreme Disaster Scenarios (EDS), and Warm Sea Surface Temperature (WSST) catalog.
